issues.description: Constructor signature mismatch for SealSaloon. The problem statement (UML and textual description) specifies a constructor SealSaloon(String) that takes the saloon name as a parameter, but both the template usage in Main and the provided solution implement/use a parameterless constructor SealSaloon(). This mismatch will confuse students about the required constructor signature (whether they must implement a constructor that accepts a String) and may cause compilation or usage confusion with the example Main code or grader expectations.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor requirement consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the template and solution to provide a public SealSaloon(String name) constructor (and adjust Main usage accordingly), or (B) update the problem statement/UML to specify a parameterless constructor. A backward-compatible approach is to provide both constructors in the SealSaloon class: a parameterless SealSaloon() and a SealSaloon(String name) that stores the name or simply calls the default constructor. This preserves the educational intent while aligning code, examples, and specification.

issues.description: Constructor signature mismatch for SealSaloon: the problem statement (diagram and text) requires a constructor SealSaloon(String) that accepts a saloon name, but both the template usage (Main.java) and the provided solution implement and instantiate a no-argument constructor SealSaloon(). This creates confusion for students about which constructor to implement and how to instantiate SealSaloon (should they pass a name or not).
issues.suggested_fix: Align the constructor expectation across artifacts. Either: (A) Update the problem statement (diagram and text) to require a no-argument constructor SealSaloon() to match the template and solution; OR (B) Change the template and solution to implement SealSaloon(String name) (store the name in a private final field and add a corresponding getter) and update all instantiations in Main to pass a saloon name. Choose one approach and apply it consistently so students have a single, unambiguous constructor signature to implement.
